contextId.occurrenceNote: Jerusalem is referred to as "her" and "she." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: I have placed her

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sickness and violent death are spoken of as if they were soldiers going through the city killing everyone they could. Alternate translation: "Many people will die of disease, and many others will die in war" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: Plague and blood will pass through you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The "end" is spoken of as if it were a robber attacking the people. Alternate translation: "your life is finished" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: the end is upon you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The judgment that is coming is treated as if it were an enemy waking up from sleep. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: The end has woken up against you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Disaster is spoken of as if it could move by itself. Alternate translation: "One disaster after another will happen" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: Disaster upon disaster will come

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the vine as if it were able to behave like a person and intentionally turned its roots toward the other eagle to receive nourishment from it. Alternate translation: "The roots of the vine grew toward the eagle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: This vine turned its roots toward the eagle

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of trees as if they are people who can know about him. The trees represent the nations and the people who live in them. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Then all the trees of the field will know that I am Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh not holding back his sword from attacking people as if his sword were a person that was no longer holding itself back from attacking. Alternate translation: "and I will not put it back in its sheath again" or "I will not hold back from attacking people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: It will no longer hold back

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the "news" as if it were a person that was soon coming to them. Alternate translation: "the news that they will soon hear" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: the news that is coming

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "sword" is personified as coming to attack the people. This speaks of the king not being able to resist the "sword", as if the "sword" were hating the king's scepter. Alternate translation: "the sword will overpower his scepter like that of any other ruler" or "for the king will not be able to resist when the sword is brought against him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: The coming sword hates every such rod

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh's sword attacking his people as if the sword itself were the attacker. Alternate translation: "I will use my sword to kill my people! I will bring it against all" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: that sword has come against my people! It is against all

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the survivors being burned by fire as if the fire were an animal attacking and eating them. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "your survivors will be burned by fire" or "fire will burn your survivors" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: your survivors will be devoured by fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: This personifies Jerusalem as a person who murdered the people and chose where to put their blood. Alternate translation: "They were murdered on the smooth rocks; not on the dirt where the dust would hide their blood" or "Their blood fell on the smooth rocks; it did not fall on the ground where the dust would cover it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: She has set it on the smooth rock; she has not poured it out on the ground to cover it with dust

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the city of Moab is spoken of with the masculine pronoun "his." Alternate translation: "starting at its cities" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: starting at his cities

contextId.occurrenceNote: The city of Tyre is spoken of here as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: "Tyre will become" or "It will become" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: She will become

contextId.occurrenceNote: The destruction of Tyre is spoken of as if it was a person who had died. Alternate translation: "you have departed" or "you exist no more" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: you are no longer in your place

contextId.occurrenceNote: What Yahweh would do to Tyre is compared to people going to the grave and cities falling into ruin. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: then I will bring you down to the people of ancient times, like the others who have gone down into the pit; for I will make you live in the lowest realms of the earth as in ruins of ancient times

contextId.occurrenceNote: "I will put Egypt into the power of desolation and waste." Desolation and waste are spoken of as if they were people who could be given power over Egypt. Alternate translation: "I will cause Egypt to become a desolate waste" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: I will give the land of Egypt over to desolation and waste

contextId.occurrenceNote: The day is spoken of as if it were able to keep its own light from shining. Alternate translation: "the day will be dark" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: the day will hold back its light

contextId.occurrenceNote: "the mountain of Seir." Yahweh tells Ezekiel to speak to Mount Seir as if it could hear him. The message is for all of the people of Edom. Alternate translation: "Mount Seir and prophesy against it because of what the people of Edom have done" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: Mount Seir and prophesy against it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh tells Ezekiel to speak to Mount Seir as if it could hear him. The message is for all of the people of Edom. Alternate translation: "Listen, Mount Seir, I will strike you with my hand and make you a desolation and a waste because of what your people did" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: Behold! I am against you, Mount Seir, and I will strike you with my hand and make you a desolation and a waste

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "bloodshed" is a metonym for killing. Yahweh speaks of bloodshed as if it were a person who could chase them. Alternate translation: "your enemies will chase you down and kill you you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: bloodshed will pursue you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "You" refers to the mountain of Seir. Ezekiel is to speak to the mountain as if it can hear him. The message is for the people of Edom. Alternate translation: "Your people said" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: You have said

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "you" refers to Mount Seir, but the message is for the people of Edom. The abstract noun "desolation" can be stated as an adjective. Alternate translation: "Because of what your people did I will make you desolate" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: I will make you a desolation

contextId.occurrenceNote: God wants Ezekiel to speak to the mountains as if they were people. The message is for the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: prophesy to the mountains of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the mountains as if they were able to hear when people insult them. Alternate translation: "I will no longer allow the other nations to insult you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: Nor will I allow you to hear the insults of the nations any longer

contextId.occurrenceNote: Experiencing shame is spoken of as if the mountains could bear shame. Alternate translation: "the peoples will no longer cause you to feel ashamed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you will no longer have to bear the shame of the peoples

contextId.occurrenceNote: "I will call the grain to come." This phrase presents the grain as a servant of Yahweh. Alternate translation: "I will cause there to be grain in the land of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: I will summon the grain
